channel.title: Bloomberg Economics

item.title: Trump Says Aug. 1 Tariff Deadline Won’t Be Extended
item.description: President Donald Trump said he would not offer any extensions for the implementation of increased tariffs on many goods imported into the US, pledging that new rates would hit at the beginning of August.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Lai

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump Photographer: Andrew Caballero-Reynolds/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: US Immigration Curbs to Hit Economy Hard in 2025, Fed Study Says
item.description: The Trump administration’s curbs on immigration and ramped-up deportations will lower US economic growth by almost a full percentage point this year, according to a study from the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas.
item.dc:creator: Catarina Saraiva

media:content.media:description: A man says goodbye to a woman as Federal agents detain him following an immigration court hearing at Jacob K. Javits Federal Building in New York, on June 10. Photographer: Adam Gray/Getty Images

item.title: BOJ Faces Inflation Risks and Has Room for Hikes, Nakaso Says
item.description: The Bank of Japan must be vigilant to upside inflation risks and has room to hike interest rates further, according to former Deputy Governor Hiroshi Nakaso.
item.dc:creator: Jana Randow, Mark Schroers, Toru Fujioka

media:content.media:description: Hiroshi Nakaso, chairman of Daiwa Institute of Research Ltd., speaks at the FinCity Global Forum in Tokyo, Japan, on Thursday, Feb. 2, 2023. The event is part of a financial promotion project by FinCity.Tokyo, an organization set up to boost the attractiveness of Tokyo as a financial center. Photographer: Kiyoshi Ota/Bloomberg

item.title: Will Trade War Make South India the Next Manufacturing Hub?
item.description: States like Tamil Nadu are dangling tax breaks and fast-tracking infrastructure, helping the country shake off its reputation as a difficult place to do business.
item.dc:creator: Dan Strumpf, Ruchi Bhatia

media:content.media:description: Putting the finishing touches on Ather scooters at the company’s factory in Hosur, Tamil Nadu.

item.title: Treasury Secretary Bessent to Visit Japan Next Week for Expo
item.description: US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent is planning to visit Japan next week for the 2025 World Expo in Osaka, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Erica Yokoyama, Takashi Umekawa

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent, US treasury secretary, during a news conference in the James S. Brady Press Briefing Room of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, June 27, 2025. President Trump says the US has made a trade deal with “probably four or five different countries,” naming agreements with China and the UK.

item.title: How Bulgaria Got to Join the Euro, and What It Means
item.description: Eighteen years after Bulgaria joined the European Union, the bloc’s finance ministers have finally cleared the way for it to adopt the euro currency in January 2026.
item.dc:creator: Slav Okov

media:content.media:description: Customers at outdoor cafe tables on Vitosha Boulevard during hot weather in Sofia, Bulgaria, on Wednesday, Aug. 14, 2024. Bulgaria is poised to hold a seventh general election in less than four years as a final attempt to form a government failed after the Black Sea nation went to the polls in June.

item.title: Zimbabwe Hopes to Service External Debt, Doesn’t Say When
item.description: Zimbabwe, locked out of international capital markets since defaulting in 1999, expects its stronger economy to help it pay back external creditors, without saying when this would begin.
item.dc:creator: Godfrey Marawanyika

media:content.media:description: The central business district of Harare, Zimbabwe.

item.title: New BOJ Board Member Hints at Possibility of Raising Price Outlook
item.description: One of the Bank of Japan’s newest board members alluded to a possible upward revision to the central bank’s inflation view this month, an outcome that would keep open the possibility of another rate increase this year.
item.dc:creator: Toru Fujioka, Sumio Ito

media:content.media:description: The Bank of Japan headquarters in Tokyo.

item.title: Inflation Expectations Return to Pre-Tariff Levels in Fed Survey
item.description: Consumer expectations for future inflation have settled back to levels last seen at the beginning of the year, prior to the announcement of aggressive new tariffs, according to monthly survey data released Tuesday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
item.dc:creator: Maria Eloisa Capurro

media:content.media:description: A shopper at a store in downtown Detroit, Michigan, US, on Saturday, June 7, 2025. The Bureau of Labor Statistics is scheduled to release US consumer price index (CPI) figures on June 11.

item.title: South Africa’s Ramaphosa Sees Room to Cut US Tariff in Talks
item.description: South African President Cyril Ramaphosa said there’s the prospect that the US may lower a planned 30% tariff on goods in ongoing talks with Washington, as he challenged its calculation of the new levy.
item.dc:creator: S'thembile Cele

item.title: Brazil’s Lula Hosts Modi in Bid to Turn India Into a Major Trade Partner
item.description: Brazilian President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva wants to deepen trade ties with India, the world’s most populous nation. The question as he prepares to host Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi in Brasilia on Tuesday is how to go about it.
item.dc:creator: Simone Iglesias, Daniel Carvalho

media:content.media:description: Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, left, and Narendra Modi, India’s prime minister

item.title: Wall Street Bank Stocks’ Furious Rally Spurs HSBC Downgrades
item.description: HSBC is turning cautious on three of the biggest US bank stocks following a record rally that’s brought the group within shouting distance of an all-time high.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Griffin

media:content.media:description: A HSBC bank branch in Enfield, UK.

item.title: ECB to Clarify Use of Unconventional Tools: Villeroy
item.description: The European Central Bank will make clear in future whether it’s deploying unconventional tools to steer the monetary-policy stance or ensure smooth transmission, Governing Council member Francois Villeroy de Galhau said.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Langley, Mark Schroers

media:content.media:description: Governor of France's central bank Francois Villeroy De Galhau.

item.title: UK Debt Looks ‘Unsustainable’ as Pension Exodus Adds to Woes
item.description: Britain is at risk of a £22 billion ($29.9 billion) surge in debt-interest costs as pension schemes buy fewer government bonds, threatening to worsen an “unsustainable” outlook for the public finances.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees, Irina Anghel

item.title: Chile Prices Tumble More Than Expected as Rate Cut Looms
item.description: Chile’s consumer prices fell twice as much as expected in June, pushing annual inflation to its lowest since September and fueling expectations that the central bank will resume interest rate cuts this month.
item.dc:creator: Antonia Mufarech

media:content.media:description: Souvenirs for sale at the Plaza de Armas in Santiago, Chile, on Sunday, June 1, 2025. Chile’s economy grew more than expected in April as mining output jumped, offsetting a drop in manufacturing and retail, according to the central bank’s main gauge of monthly activity. Photographer: Cristobal Olivares/Bloomberg

item.title: New Zealand Home-Building Costs Contained by Cooling Demand
item.description: New Zealand home-building costs rose modestly in the second quarter as cooling demand for new dwellings suppresses wages and material prices in the construction industry.
item.dc:creator: Tracy Withers

item.title: Romania Holds Rates With Emergency Tax Hikes Set to Boost Prices
item.description: Romania’s central bank left borrowing costs unchanged as government efforts to rein in the ballooning budget deficit with tax hikes are likely to trigger a temporary spike in inflation.
item.dc:creator: Andra Timu, Irina Vilcu

item.title: Cautionary Signals Emerge in Latest US Jobs Report
item.description: An assortment of cautionary signals emerged in the latest US jobs report, including weak and concentrated hiring in the private sector as well as a dip in hours worked that underscore a fragile job market.
item.dc:creator: Augusta Saraiva

media:content.media:description: Job seekers attend a job fair in Chicago, Illinois.

item.title: Latest Tariff Pause Shows Limits of Trump’s Frenzied Dealmaking
item.description: On “Liberation Day” on April 2, Donald Trump gushed about how trade was finally going to tilt in America’s favor after decades of its workers and companies being “plundered.” For the president, unfettered tariffs would soon make the US “an entirely different country.”
item.dc:creator: Jenny Leonard

item.title: Trump’s Tariff Warning Letters Upset Peak Shipping Season
item.description: President Donald Trump issued his first round of trade letters Monday, setting new rates for more than a dozen countries, while pushing back the deadline for “reciprocal” tariffs until Aug 1.
item.dc:creator: Laura Curtis

item.title: Trump’s Letters to the World Threaten Tariff Pain
item.description: I’m Craig Stirling, a senior editor in Frankfurt. Today we’re looking at Donald Trump’s latest trade salvos. Send us feedback and tips to ecodaily@bloomberg.net. And if you aren’t yet signed up to receive this newsletter, you can do so here.
item.dc:creator: Craig Stirling

item.title: German Exports Fall More Than Expected as US Shipments Sink
item.description: German exports sank more than anticipated in May as the value of shipments to the US plunged to their lowest level in more than three years amid President Donald Trump’s tariff threats.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers

media:content.media:description: Vehicles bound for export at the Port of Barcelona. Photographer: Angel Garcia/Bloomberg

item.title: Indonesia’s Chief Negotiator Heads to US to Discuss Tariffs
item.description: Indonesia will immediately resume tariff negotiations with the US to lower the 32% tariff that President Donald Trump threatens to impose starting August, while working to diversify its trade with other export markets.
item.dc:creator: Grace Sihombing, Claire Jiao

media:content.media:description: Airlangga Hartarto Photographer: Yasuyoshi Chiba/Getty Images

item.title: US Small-Business Optimism Fell Slightly Before Trump Tax Bill
item.description: Sentiment among US small businesses fell slightly in June as owners continued to worry about taxes ahead of a major legislative win for the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Georgina Boos

media:content.media:description: A hardware store in San Francisco.

item.title: Milei’s Secret Weapon Is an Anti-Woke Devotee of ‘The West Wing’
item.description: Santiago Caputo is upending Argentine politics amid rumored tension with the libertarian president’s sister ahead of a crucial midterm vote.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Tobias

media:content.media:description: Tattoos peek through Santiago Caputo’s sleeves outside the Casa Rosada in Buenos Aires.

item.title: EU Increasingly Trades With Autocrats and Dictators, ECB Research Shows
item.description: Europe’s trading partners have become less democratic over the past quarter century, contrary to a commitment by governments to pay attention to political, human and social rights, according to research published by the European Central Bank.
item.dc:creator: Jana Randow

media:content.media:description: Trade with China accounts for about one-fifth of all imports into the EU.

item.title: US Clouds Malaysia Rate Path With Surprise 25% Tariff Threat
item.description: The surprise US decision to raise its threatened tariff on Malaysia to 25% means trade will almost certainly dominate the Southeast Asian nation’s interest rate decision on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Anisah Shukry

item.title: US Tariff Delay Might Soften Christmas Impact, UBS’ Donovan Says
item.description: Donald Trump’s delay of tariff increases until Aug. 1 may have just softened the price impact for Christmas by pushing it into 2026, according to UBS Group AG Chief Economist Paul Donovan.
item.dc:creator: Craig Stirling

media:content.media:description: Toys imported from abroad line the shelves of a toy store in Miami Beach.

item.title: Japan Gets 25% Tariffs With Room to Seek Deal Past Election
item.description: Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba called the announcement of slightly higher US tariffs “truly regrettable” while he vowed to continue to protect his nation’s interests in the extended trade negotiations.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara

item.title: Naira Decouples from Oil as Confidence in Nigerian Reforms Grows
item.description: Nigeria’s currency appears to be decoupling from the price of oil, the nation’s main foreign-exchange earner.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Osae-Brown, Emele Onu
